column23: In the areas for improvement section, more details could be provided, for example, indicating the most appropriate data structures for the exercise.

column11:

It is "personal" but feels like data fed into an LLM to generate some comments and steps that ultimately mean nothing.

And if I have problems navegate with in the application I can see me getting shame of it. I like however the positive messages and some of the numbers that are given.

column41: I like how it has an conclusion and a summary so I can looks at both to decide if I want to go futher, and like the sections in wicht the information was devided. I would only had some numbers in some places like in option A so the teachers have something more concrete to looks after.
column43: I don't like how there's a ênfase on the time spent in the menu.as there may be multiple reasons as to why someone is wasting time with it.

column11: I really liked option A because of the existence of precise metrics (time) that allowed me to know where I wasted a lot of time and where I have improved, I think there could be an average to compare such time
column17: Unlike option A, option B presents less precise feedback, mostly due to the lack of metrics (in this case time) which makes the feedback less clear to understand due to using more relative language instead of using more precise metrics, other than that, option B presents more feedback and recommendations, something that can be useful.
column23: Option C proves to be more direct with what it wants to explain, the use of bullet points makes the information clearer and more effective, but I feel that the information given is more comprehensive and less tailored to the individual user, which makes it less useful.
column29: Option A shows precise metrics that help the teacher to compare with other students, adding average metrics further helps the teacher to know if the student is above or below the target.
column35: Option B shows many comparison metrics, which helps the teacher to evaluate the student's performance. This option also shows the student's weaknesses, but I think it should have more recommendations for that student.
column41: Option C shows few metrics but uses bullet points, which is an excellent way of giving feedback effectively.
column43: I really liked the use of bullet points in option C, I believe that for a student the information should be given effectively and bullet points make this happen, the use of metrics in option A makes comparing students easier.

column17: Don't mention the interactions with the menu
column35: I like this option so far
column43: Option C in the first question and option B on the second, I think they provide a good amount of information

column11: The feedback is too verbose and generic, I think it should be made much more succinct, or else it can be tiresome to read. Also, the recommended actions are very vague rather than concrete. Finally, it was not well understood how there were 49 breakdowns on the GRAPHICS section just by looking visually, maybe the feedback should not focus so much on the numbers but rather on their relative value (i.e. when compared with other metrics).
column17: The response is well structured. However, it seems it takes conclusions very surely from the given data, even when there can be multiple possible interpretations. It feels like the model is providing information for the sake of it. For instance, in my opinion, the proportion of time spent by the student on the CODING section compared to the MENU section seemed fair, as it is expected that CODING should take longer than MENU. Perhaps the model does not have full understanding of the subject matter to take informed conclusions. Rather, it tries to keep a balance in various aspects, even when that may not be the goal. Of course, data interpretation is very opinionated, but I think the model should take that into account instead of stating things as fact. It may make the students feel misunderstood.
column23: The response feels very generic and disconnected from the actual student data. I think this model also falls into the trap of providing information for the sake of it, simply to make the response feel "complete" (e.g. having always 3 bullet points per section). Some insights just do not seem to make sense, such as the strength of "Breakdown details" (it seems like it is evaluating the UI rather than the student) and "Practice more" (what is "accuracy" in this context?). The conclusion that the student must have spent time reviewing past attempts or making adjustments because they were not active for 3 seconds is ridiculous. The response structure is fine, but the model should be much more succinct and avoid making unfounded conclusions or suggestions.
column29: Converting absolute differences to percentages is very useful. Most conclusions taken seem to make sense, except for the "Session breakdown" recommendation which does not seem to derive from the data or previous statements, and even seems contradictory (the response previously said that the student had good time management and was active). The model may be attempting to introduce more information than it needs. The "Implications and Enhancements" section felt a little out of place to me.
column35: The first paragraph was good, but the rest of the response was either nonsensical or generic. The conclusions taken in the second and third paragraphs are wrong and do not derive from the data. All recommendations but the first one were disconnected from the evaluated student and could be applied to many other cases. The model should spend less text developing conclusions and providing feedback from those conclusions, as they seem to be wrong.
column41: This response is nonsensical, bloated, contradictory and generic. For one the model suggests removing time in the DOCUMENTATION and MENU sections even though in this context they do not make sense as suggestions, since it may be desirable to consult these sources. In terms of content, the response contains too much embellishment and introduces points just for the sake of it (it even duplicates the second point of the "Strategy and Understanding" section). It also contradicts itself, since it also suggests reinforcing the time spent in the GRAPHICS and CODING sections even though it was recommended to spend time in the DOCUMENTATION and MENU sections instead. Finally, it also spends text in presenting statements that can be applied to pretty much any student. The response should be made much more succinct, and in that process the answer may get less bloated and contradictory statements may be avoided.
column43: I think something that is noticeable in these models (some more than the others) is that responses tend to be too large and include embellishment. Since these are snippets of feedback that the student/teacher may want to see frequently (for each challenge/student respectively), it is important that the responses are kept as succinct as possible. Maybe, since most responses are already structured like so, simply present the first paragraph which tends to be the summary, and include the other sections as collapsible boxes that the users can then open to see more info, rather than have a big answer all at once which can be hard to visually digest.

column11: I prefer white better than dark theme
column35: This question should be indicated as optional

column11: Its way too positive. While that can be good in order to motivate the student, it doesn't help them learn and grow their programming skills much. And can also be a little annoying to read due to the repeated compliments and unnecessary text. In the other hand its nice that it says congratulations and doesn't only say bad things and things they did wrong, and it's very personalized because it speaks directly with the student, using second person pronouns ("you"). A suggestion would to sugarcoat less and write less, while still being positive.
column17: It's very direct, unlike option A, which is better. It's also personalized by addressing the student directly, and even more than A because it shows important feedback of what actually happened. The only bad thing was the suggestion to read less documentation and not to go back and forth, since, for me, that practice is extremely normal and beneficial, it's always good to read again and revise. The rest of the recommendations are ok.
column23: Its not very personal because it uses third person speach. It also highlights unnecessary stats, like the little inactive time the student had. The areas of improvement and tips were good, but "practice more" was very loose.
